elements.title: Monthly-Equivalent Pricing as Primary Display
elements.problem: Guests arrive with a monthly-rent mental model built from years of traditional leasing. Shomit says 'I guess mainly I think of this per month and then I break it down per night' (line 65) and anchors his budget at 'below 2,500 a month' (line 68). The platform prices per night, forcing every guest to perform silent arithmetic at every listing touchpoint: $66/night x 4 nights x ~4.3 weeks = ?. This cognitive translation tax violates Csikszentmihalyi's immediate-feedback requirement. Instead of instantly knowing whether a listing fits their budget, the guest must compute — and computation is not feedback, it is work. The information architecture currently privileges the platform's internal pricing unit over the guest's native financial frame.
elements.solution: Make the monthly equivalent the primary price display, with per-night rate as secondary detail. Every listing card, listing page, and search result must show: (1) the monthly cost for the guest's selected schedule as the largest, most prominent number; (2) a savings comparison against the guest's reference frame ('vs. $2,500/mo full-time lease: you save $1,444'); (3) the per-night rate as supporting detail below the monthly figure. When the guest adjusts nights or weeks, the monthly figure must update in real time with zero delay.

evidence.quote: I guess mainly I think of this per month and then I break it down per night... I've had many leases I've rented in New York for a long time. I think go, like, what kind of place would I rent for myself? Right. Probably below 2,500 a month is what I would usually spend.
evidence.insight: The guest's budget framework is monthly. He explicitly describes translating from monthly to nightly — the platform forces him to work backward from his natural frame. Information architecture must present pricing in the guest's native unit first.

evidence.quote: four nights will be get $66 per night And that is including all taxes fees.
evidence.insight: The agent delivers only per-night pricing. The guest must mentally compute $66 x 4 x 4.3 to reach a monthly figure. This math should be done by the interface, not the guest.

evidence.quote: The reason it is possible to achieve such complete involvement in a flow experience is that goals are usually clear, and feedback immediate.
evidence.insight: Pricing evaluation is a feedback loop: the guest asks 'does this fit my budget?' and the listing must answer instantly. Requiring mental arithmetic inserts a delay and uncertainty that breaks the feedback loop.

evidence.quote: the experience usually occurs when we confront tasks we have a chance of completing. Second, we must be able to concentrate on what we are doing. Third and fourth, the concentration is usually possible because the task undertaken has clear goals and provides immediate feedback.
evidence.insight: Budget evaluation is a completable task only when the information is in the right unit. Presenting per-night pricing to a monthly-budget thinker makes the task feel incomplete because the answer requires additional computation steps.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Monthly equivalent cost is the PRIMARY information on every listing touchpoint. Per-night rate is SECONDARY (supporting detail). Savings comparison to full-time lease is TERTIARY (contextual reinforcement). The guest's decision is 'can I afford this per month,' so the monthly figure must be the first number the eye encounters.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Show the monthly figure immediately on every listing card in search results. Only reveal per-night breakdown when the guest interacts with the listing (hover, click, or expand). Show the savings comparison on the full listing page, not in the compact search card. Never require the guest to navigate to a calculator or separate tool.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 price number visible per listing card in search results. Maximum 3 price numbers on the full listing page (monthly cost, per-night rate, savings vs. full lease). Zero arithmetic required from the guest at any point.
exclude: Per-night rate as the primary or sole price display
Price calculator that requires the guest to input nights and compute manually
Annual cost projections at the listing evaluation phase
Pricing for schedule configurations the guest has not selected

elements.title: Progressive Co-Tenancy Disclosure Across Phases
elements.problem: The co-tenancy concept is the single most novel and potentially disorienting element of the Split Lease model. Shomit's reaction — 'I mean, I guess that's fine. I mean, it doesn't really matter to me. Well, I guess that's fine' (line 19) — demonstrates surface acceptance masking unresolved uncertainty. The triple hedge ('I guess... I guess... I guess') is a linguistic marker of incomplete processing. Currently, co-tenancy is explained once on the initial call and again at the Zoom meeting weeks later. Between these two moments, the guest carries unresolved questions through search and listing evaluation with no structured information to address them. The information architecture treats co-tenancy as a one-time disclosure event rather than a persistent information need that resurfaces at every phase.
elements.solution: Structure co-tenancy information as a progressive disclosure thread woven through four phases, each layer answering the questions that arise at that specific phase. (1) Discovery: 1-sentence concept + visual diagram ('You use the space Mon-Thu; someone else uses it Fri-Sun. You never overlap.'). (2) Listing evaluation: dedicated listing section showing what is shared, what is private, cleaning standards between transitions, storage for personal items. (3) Negotiation (Zoom prep): co-tenant profile summary, conversation guide with suggested questions, explicit statement that the guest can decline. (4) Move-in: arrival-day FAQ addressing evidence of the co-tenant (belongings, personal items), cleaning verification, and escalation path for issues.

evidence.quote: Where does that other person go? ... I mean, I guess that's fine. I mean, it doesn't really matter to me. Well, I guess that's fine.
evidence.insight: The guest's first co-tenancy question is spatial and concrete ('Where does that other person go?'). The answer he receives is abstract. The listing page must provide concrete, spatial answers: floor plan showing shared vs. private zones, photos of storage arrangements, transition-day timeline.

evidence.quote: the two people who acting sort of like ghost roommates... the same space is used by different people in different types.
evidence.insight: The agent uses the metaphor 'ghost roommates' — evocative but not informative. The guest needs structured information, not metaphors. What does 'ghost roommate' mean for my toothbrush, my closet space, my sense of privacy?

evidence.quote: these blind women stressed more than anyone else the importance of receiving clear feedback as a condition for enjoying whatever they were doing. Unable to see what was going on around them, they needed to know even more than sighted people whether what they were trying to accomplish was actually coming to pass.
evidence.insight: Guests evaluating a co-tenancy arrangement remotely are in an analogous position to the blind women: they cannot see the shared-living reality. They need richer, more explicit information to compensate for the absence of direct sensory experience. The listing must provide feedback that closes the gap between concept and reality.

evidence.quote: Another universally enjoyable activity is being with other people... But of course, it does [require skills]; as so many shy people know, if a person feels self-conscious, he or she will dread establishing informal contacts, and avoid company whenever possible.
evidence.insight: The Zoom co-tenant meeting is a social interaction requiring interpersonal skills. Without preparation materials and structured guidance, it becomes a source of anxiety rather than a confidence-building step. The information architecture must prepare the guest before the meeting, not just schedule it.

elements.hierarchy_principle: At each phase, the co-tenancy information that matters most is the information that answers the phase-specific question. Discovery: 'What is this arrangement?' (concept). Listing evaluation: 'What will my daily experience be like?' (practicalities). Negotiation: 'Who is this person and will I be comfortable?' (social). Move-in: 'Is the space actually as described?' (verification). Each phase's primary co-tenancy information is the answer to that phase's question.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Discovery: 1 sentence + 1 diagram, no detail about cleaning or storage yet. Listing page: expandable section with shared/private zones, cleaning protocol, storage arrangements — only revealed when the guest has engaged with the listing (scrolled past photos and pricing). Zoom prep: delivered 24-48 hours before the meeting as a standalone guide, not buried in the listing. Move-in: included in the arrival packet alongside keys and house rules, not in a separate document the guest must find.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Discovery co-tenancy explanation: maximum 25 words + 1 visual. Listing co-tenancy section: maximum 5 information items (shared zones, private zones, cleaning standard, storage, transition timeline). Zoom prep guide: maximum 1 page with 5 suggested questions. Move-in co-tenancy FAQ: maximum 5 Q&A pairs.
scan_order: Visual diagram of space usage split
What is private to me vs. shared
How to address concerns if they arise
exclude: Co-tenant's personal information before the Zoom meeting is scheduled
Detailed cleaning protocols at the discovery phase — too much detail too early creates anxiety
Legal co-tenancy terms in the listing evaluation phase — save for acceptance
Co-tenant's schedule details before the guest has committed to a bid — this is noise before the guest has chosen a listing

elements.title: Process Progress Visibility with Phase-Specific Next Steps
elements.problem: The guest journey spans two to three weeks across five distinct phases, but the guest has no persistent visibility into where they are in the process or what comes next. The agent describes the process linearly on the call — bid, match, Zoom, lease — but this verbal map disappears the moment the call ends. Shomit's metaphor 'so like courtship' (line 61) reveals how the guest experiences the process: as an open-ended, uncertain pursuit with no guaranteed endpoint. Csikszentmihalyi identifies clear goals and immediate feedback as prerequisites for sustained engagement. The current information architecture provides neither: the guest takes an action (places a bid) and enters a feedback void until the next human contact.
elements.solution: Implement a persistent process tracker visible on every platform page after account creation. The tracker shows: (1) all phases as named steps (Browse > Express Interest > Match > Meet > Lease); (2) the guest's current position highlighted; (3) the specific next action required from the guest at this moment; (4) estimated time to the next milestone. After each guest action, the tracker updates immediately with a confirmation message and the next expected event. Between milestones, the platform sends status updates at least every 48 hours via the guest's preferred channel (email or SMS).

evidence.quote: It's usually takes two or three weeks to finish the process and get Lisa [lease].
evidence.insight: A multi-week process with no intermediate visibility creates a sustained feedback vacuum. The guest must hold the entire process map in memory from a single phone call. The information architecture must externalize this map as a persistent, visible artifact.

evidence.quote: So like courtship.
evidence.insight: The courtship metaphor reveals the guest perceives the process as uncertain and bidirectional — both parties are evaluating. The process tracker must acknowledge this by showing what the platform is doing for the guest (matching, scheduling, preparing lease) alongside what the guest needs to do, reinforcing that the platform is an active participant, not a passive intermediary.

evidence.quote: Certain activities require a very long time to accomplish, yet the components of goals and feedback are still extremely important to them... 'I find special satisfaction in caring for the plants: I like to see them grow day by day. It is very beautiful.'
evidence.insight: Even multi-week processes sustain engagement when progress is visible. The process tracker is the digital equivalent of watching plants grow — it provides incremental feedback that the guest's effort is producing results, even during waiting periods.

evidence.quote: The kind of feedback we work toward is in and of itself often unimportant: What difference does it make if I hit the tennis ball between the white lines... What makes this information valuable is the symbolic message it contains: that I have succeeded in my goal. Such knowledge creates order in consciousness.
evidence.insight: Process progress indicators are symbolically important even when the update is small ('Your bid is being reviewed'). The symbolic message — 'you are advancing toward your housing goal' — creates order in the guest's consciousness and sustains engagement through waiting periods.

elements.hierarchy_principle: The process tracker is PERSISTENT infrastructure — always visible, never the primary content but never absent. On any page, the tracker is SECONDARY to the page's primary content (listings, bid form, meeting details) but always accessible. The current next action is the PRIMARY information within the tracker itself, with completed steps as TERTIARY context.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Show only the current step and immediate next step in the compact tracker view. Expand to show all steps on click or hover. Never show all steps expanded by default — this overwhelms with process complexity before the guest is ready. After a milestone is completed, briefly highlight the advancement (animation, color change) before returning to the compact view focused on the next step.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 5 named steps in the full tracker. Maximum 1 next-action displayed in the compact view. Status update messages: maximum 2 sentences. Time estimates: specific date ranges, not vague durations ('expected by Feb 25' not 'in about a week').
scan_order: Current step highlighted in the tracker
exclude: Detailed descriptions of future steps the guest has not yet reached
Process steps that are internal-only (matching algorithm, landlord approval) — show outcomes, not machinery
Percentage-complete indicators — the process is not linear enough for percentages to be meaningful
Countdown timers that create artificial urgency rather than genuine feedback

elements.title: Comparison-First Search Results Architecture
elements.problem: Shomit refuses to act on any single listing until he has surveyed the full landscape: 'No, I want to see what the other options are' (line 52). He repeats this stance three times across the call. The agent describes the website as a place to 'play with' options dynamically (line 49), setting an expectation of interactive comparison. But comparison requires specific information architecture: the guest must be able to see multiple listings simultaneously with consistent data points aligned for side-by-side evaluation. If each listing must be opened, read, remembered, and then compared from memory against the next, the cognitive load exceeds what Csikszentmihalyi calls the guest's 'capacity to act' and produces the anxiety-zone behavior Shomit demonstrates (deferral, refusal to commit).
elements.solution: Architect search results for comparison, not sequential browsing. This means: (1) Each listing card in search results displays the same 4 data points in the same position: monthly cost for selected schedule, neighborhood, available nights, and a quality indicator (rating or photo thumbnail). (2) A 'Compare' function allows the guest to select 2-3 listings and see them side-by-side in a structured comparison view with all key attributes aligned row by row. (3) Filter controls are persistent and visible, not hidden behind a button. Each filter change immediately updates results with zero page reload. (4) The guest's selected schedule (nights, duration) is set once at the top and applies to all results, so every listing shows pricing for the same configuration.

evidence.quote: No, I want to see what the other options are.
evidence.insight: The guest's primary need in search is breadth before depth. He wants to see the landscape before examining any single option. The information architecture must support scanning across multiple listings quickly, not funneling toward a single listing.

evidence.quote: Other options are good. I like the upper west side, but it's not the only place. I mean, there's other options that might be good to know about.
evidence.insight: Shomit is open to exploring beyond his initial preference but needs to see alternatives to evaluate them. The search must surface relevant alternatives proactively, not only what matches the guest's first stated preference.

evidence.quote: you can play with that on the website and it will give you all options dynamically. So you can see that.
evidence.insight: The agent sets an expectation of dynamic, interactive search. The information architecture must deliver on this promise: real-time filter updates, instant price recalculation on schedule change, and a sense of responsive 'play' that matches Csikszentmihalyi's challenge-skill balance for exploratory activities.

evidence.quote: Enjoyment appears at the boundary between boredom and anxiety, when the challenges are just balanced with the person's capacity to act.
evidence.insight: Comparing listings from memory (open listing A, remember details, go back, open listing B, compare from memory) is a challenge that exceeds most guests' working memory capacity. Side-by-side comparison brings the challenge within the guest's capacity to act, enabling the engaged evaluation state that precedes confident action.

elements.hierarchy_principle: In search results, the COMPARATIVE information (the 4 data points that differ between listings) is PRIMARY. The DESCRIPTIVE information (property narrative, host story, detailed amenities) is SECONDARY, revealed only when the guest clicks into a specific listing. The FILTER CONTROLS are PERSISTENT infrastructure — always visible alongside results so the guest can iterate without losing context.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Level 1 (search results grid): 4 standardized data points per listing card. Level 2 (listing preview on hover or quick-view): key photos + 2-sentence summary + schedule availability. Level 3 (full listing page): complete description, all photos, co-tenancy details, neighborhood info. Never force the guest to Level 3 to access the data points needed for comparison — those must be at Level 1.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 4 data points per listing card in search results. Maximum 8 listings visible per search results page without scrolling. The comparison view supports maximum 3 listings simultaneously. Schedule selector: maximum 2 interactions to set (select nights, select duration).
exclude: Detailed property descriptions in search result cards — descriptions belong on the full listing page
Amenity lists in search results — amenities are evaluation-phase information, not search-phase
Bid counts or popularity indicators that create artificial urgency before the guest has completed comparison
Co-tenancy details in search results — this is listing-evaluation information, not search-comparison information

elements.title: Physical Verification Pathway as Explicit Listing Feature
elements.problem: Shomit asks 'is it possible to see the unit? Is that allowed?' (line 29). The phrasing 'is that allowed?' reveals two information architecture failures: (1) the guest does not know whether physical viewing is possible, and (2) the guest is uncertain whether the platform's model even supports it. For a guest with extensive NYC rental experience — where in-person viewing is standard practice — this uncertainty undermines the entire evaluation. Csikszentmihalyi's feedback principle applies directly: the guest cannot complete their evaluation without sensory confirmation that the space matches the digital representation. The current information architecture does not surface the physical verification option; the guest must ask for it, and even then, the answer is ambiguous.
elements.solution: Make physical verification an explicit, prominent feature on every listing page. This means: (1) A 'Visit this property' call-to-action on the listing page, positioned after photos and pricing but before the bid button. (2) If in-person visits are available: show scheduling options with available dates. (3) If in-person visits are not available: compensate with a dedicated 'Virtual Tour' section containing video walkthrough, 360-degree photos, and photos of the space in its actual lived-in state (not staged). (4) In either case, include a 'Verification' badge or section that shows: last cleaning inspection date, property condition rating, and any relevant third-party verification.

evidence.quote: is it possible to see the unit? Is that allowed?
evidence.insight: The guest must ask whether a standard rental practice (viewing the unit) is even possible. This information should be proactively surfaced on the listing, not discovered through a question. 'Is that allowed?' signals the guest perceives the platform as potentially restrictive — the listing must counter this by explicitly offering verification options.

evidence.quote: I've had many leases I've rented in New York for a long time.
evidence.insight: Extensive rental experience creates a strong expectation baseline. The guest's internal standard for evaluation includes physical viewing. The information architecture must either meet this standard or explicitly provide an equivalent that the guest can trust as a substitute.

evidence.quote: these blind women stressed more than anyone else the importance of receiving clear feedback as a condition for enjoying whatever they were doing. Unable to see what was going on around them, they needed to know even more than sighted people whether what they were trying to accomplish was actually coming to pass.
evidence.insight: Remote listing evaluation is structurally analogous to the blind women's experience: the guest cannot see the physical reality. The information architecture must compensate by providing richer-than-usual visual feedback — video, 360 photos, lived-in-condition photos — that narrows the gap between digital representation and physical reality.

elements.hierarchy_principle: The physical verification pathway is SECONDARY on the listing page — it sits below the primary evaluation information (pricing, photos, schedule) but above the commitment action (bid button). This placement reflects the guest's natural decision sequence: evaluate digitally, verify physically (or virtually), then decide. The verification option must never be TERTIARY or hidden; it must be encountered before the guest reaches the bid prompt.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Show the verification option (visit or virtual tour) as a visible section on the listing page during the guest's first visit. If the guest returns to the same listing, elevate the verification section higher on the page — repeat visits signal deeper evaluation interest. Do not gate the verification option behind a bid or account action; it must be freely accessible to support the guest's evaluation process.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Verification section on the listing page: maximum 1 call-to-action ('Schedule a Visit' or 'Take Virtual Tour') plus maximum 3 supporting details (available dates, tour duration, what to expect). Virtual tour: maximum 3 minutes. Lived-in-condition photo set: maximum 8 photos covering key spaces.
scan_order: Verification availability indicator (can I visit or tour?)
How to access verification (schedule link or tour button)
What the verification covers (which rooms, what condition)
exclude: Verification requirements (deposit, ID check) before the guest has expressed interest in visiting — don't add friction before confirming the option exists
Detailed cleaning logs or inspection reports at the listing-evaluation stage — a summary indicator is sufficient
Co-tenant's personal effects in lived-in photos — show the space's condition, not the co-tenant's lifestyle

elements.title: Single-Concept Phase Introduction
elements.problem: During the initial call, the agent introduces the full Split Lease model in a single block: co-tenancy concept, ghost roommates metaphor, schedule splitting, cost savings, bid system, non-binding bids, matching process, Zoom meeting, lease timeline (lines 11-62). This is at least six novel concepts delivered in one interaction. Shomit's partial acceptance — 'this is good, right? Except for like one or two things' (line 23) — shows he absorbed the value proposition but has unresolved concerns. Yet the agent continues introducing more complexity (bids, matching, timeline) before resolving those concerns. Csikszentmihalyi's challenge-skill balance principle predicts the outcome: when process complexity exceeds the guest's current capacity to absorb it, the guest retreats to 'protective routines' — in Shomit's case, the repeated 'I'll hold off.'
elements.solution: Architect each phase introduction to present exactly one new concept, with all supporting information structured to serve that single concept. (1) Discovery: only the value proposition — 'A furnished apartment for the nights you need, at a fraction of full-time rent.' No bids, no matching, no co-tenancy details. (2) Search: only the schedule-price relationship — 'Select your nights and see your monthly cost.' Introduce dynamic pricing through interaction, not explanation. (3) Proposal creation: only the expression of interest — 'Mark this property as one you want. This is not a commitment.' Introduce the bid concept only after the guest has selected a preferred listing. (4) Negotiation: only the co-tenant meeting — 'Meet the person who uses the space on different days. You decide if you are comfortable.' Introduce the Zoom meeting only after a match is confirmed.

evidence.quote: let me just a quick explain you how's this work to make sure we all the same page... the two people who acting sort of like ghost roommates... the same space is used by different people... the cost for you is significantly less.
evidence.insight: The agent introduces co-tenancy, schedule splitting, and cost savings in a single block. Each of these is a novel concept that requires its own processing time. Stacking them produces partial absorption at best.

evidence.quote: I guess like a few, this is good, right? Except for like one or two things.
evidence.insight: The guest signals he has grasped the core value ('this is good') but has unresolved items ('except for one or two things'). The information architecture at each phase should resolve the current concept fully before introducing the next one.

evidence.quote: Enjoyment appears at the boundary between boredom and anxiety, when the challenges are just balanced with the person's capacity to act.
evidence.insight: Six novel concepts in one interaction exceeds the guest's capacity. Each concept should be introduced at the phase where the guest has the context and motivation to absorb it — when it is the natural next challenge in their journey, not a preview of future complexity.

evidence.quote: Any activity contains a bundle of opportunities for action, or 'challenges,' that require appropriate skills to realize. For those who don't have the right skills, the activity is not challenging; it is simply meaningless.
evidence.insight: Being told about bids before seeing listings, or about Zoom meetings before having a match, makes those concepts meaningless to the guest — they lack the experiential context to make the information actionable. Information architecture must sequence disclosure to match experiential readiness.

elements.hierarchy_principle: At each phase introduction, the single new concept is PRIMARY — it occupies the visual and cognitive center. Supporting details for that concept are SECONDARY. All information about future phases is EXCLUDED entirely. The guest should never see a concept they cannot act on in their current phase.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Each phase opens with a single orienting statement (maximum 15 words) that names the one new concept. Supporting detail unfolds only as the guest interacts. Future phase concepts are never previewed, teased, or summarized. The guest discovers the next concept only when they arrive at the next phase. Exception: the process tracker (communicates-003) shows phase names but not phase details.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 novel concept introduced per phase. Maximum 15 words for the introductory statement. Maximum 3 supporting details for the new concept per phase. Zero references to phases the guest has not yet reached, except in the process tracker's step names.
scan_order: Action the guest can take now
exclude: Explanations of future phases in the current phase introduction
Process diagrams showing all steps at once (use the progressive tracker from communicates-003 instead)
FAQ sections that pre-answer questions the guest has not yet formed — these signal complexity rather than reducing it
Comparative explanations to traditional renting at every phase — do this once at discovery, then let the platform speak for itself

elements.title: Action Reframing from 'Bid' to 'Save' at Proposal Stage
elements.problem: The word 'bid' carries semantic weight from auctions and competitive contexts: obligation, competition, financial commitment. Despite the agent explaining three times that bids are non-binding (lines 34, 53-54, 59), Shomit refuses to place one. The information-level problem is not that the guest lacks knowledge (he understands the non-binding nature) but that the label 'bid' activates a mental model incompatible with the actual action. Csikszentmihalyi's paradox of control applies: the guest 'cannot experience a feeling of control unless one is willing to give up the safety of protective routines' (lines 727-728). The word 'bid' invokes a high-stakes frame that makes the protective routine ('I'll hold off') feel safer than acting.
elements.solution: Replace 'bid' in all guest-facing information architecture with language that accurately reflects the non-binding, exploratory nature of the action. Recommended alternatives: 'Save this property,' 'Express interest,' or 'Add to my shortlist.' The action button, confirmation message, and all references to this step must use the same reframed language consistently. The information hierarchy around this action should emphasize: (1) what the action does NOT do (does not commit you, does not charge you, does not notify the landlord); (2) what it DOES do (saves the property to your list, starts the matching process if you choose to proceed); (3) how to undo it (you can remove it from your shortlist at any time).

evidence.quote: I would suggest entering the beat for this property... a bead is not Samsung, which obligates you to lease it. It's your expression of interest for certain properties.
evidence.insight: The agent must spend significant call time overcoming the semantic weight of 'bid.' The word requires immediate correction every time it is used. Information architecture should eliminate this friction by using language that does not need correction.

evidence.quote: I'll still hold off. See the other ones.
evidence.insight: After three explanations that bids are non-binding, the guest still 'holds off.' The information problem is not comprehension but framing. The label activates the wrong mental model, and no amount of explanation can fully override the label's semantic weight.

evidence.quote: what people enjoy is not the sense of being in control, but the sense of exercising control in difficult situations. It is not possible to experience a feeling of control unless one is willing to give up the safety of protective routines.
evidence.insight: The guest will only take action when they feel the action is an exercise of control, not a surrender of it. 'Save to my shortlist' frames the action as the guest organizing their options (exercising control). 'Place a bid' frames the action as the guest entering a competitive process (surrendering control to an external system).

elements.hierarchy_principle: The reframed action label ('Save' or 'Express Interest') is PRIMARY on the listing page action area. The explanation of what this action means is SECONDARY — a brief tooltip or line below the button. The detailed non-binding disclaimer is TERTIARY — available on expansion but not cluttering the action area. The action must feel lightweight and reversible, not formal and consequential.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The action button shows only the reframed label ('Save this property'). On hover or click, a brief tooltip confirms: 'Saves to your shortlist. No commitment. Remove anytime.' Only if the guest seeks more detail (clicks 'learn more' or accesses FAQ) do they see the full matching process explanation. Never front-load the matching process explanation on the action button itself — this adds weight to what should feel weightless.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Action button: maximum 4 words. Tooltip: maximum 12 words. The guest should be able to complete the action in under 3 seconds without reading any supporting text. Zero legal or disclaimer language visible at the action moment.
scan_order: Brief confirmation of what happens next
exclude: The word 'bid' in any guest-facing interface element
Legal disclaimers or terms at the point of action — these belong in the acceptance phase
Competitive framing ('X other guests are interested in this property') at the proposal stage — this reintroduces the high-stakes frame the reframing is designed to eliminate
Detailed matching process explanation at the action moment — save for after the action is taken
